-2-
so good.
However, Frederick told me rather proudly that his
father
spoke Russian, French,
German, Turkish,
Chinese and
Japanese
fluently.
Four buildings which he owned had been
destroyed by American bombing raids during the war.
Sunday we went to see the famous
Takarazuka
girls
opera.
The
theatre is owned by the PAA agents in Osaka who
also put on the show.
The play was a Japanese version of
Romeo and Juliet, in which all the players were girls.
The
ending was a new
version which might or might not appeal to
William
Shakespeare.
After the scene where Romeo dies of
poison and Juliet kills herself,
the curtain came down and
the
"Takarazuka
Ballet"', a copy
of the
"Rockettes" denced
across the wide stage.
The bandy-legged girls danced as
though each were carrying a safe on her back.
They would
give a great leap which almost - but not quite - took them
off the floor.
I sat next to the President and could hardly
keep from laughing at the wrong time.
Presently the "Rockettes"
made
their
ponderous way off the stage and the curtain
rose on
a scene
in
the
clouds where Romeo and Juliet, complete with tin
halos,
climb hand in hand up to heaven.
We went backstege with
the President and he lined up the entire cast to make a photo-
graph of us in heaven !
We drove back to our host's for a Turkish dinner
which I can't describe and do not know what I ate, but
everything was
good.
Monday we spent with our agents in Osaka and Kobe
and had dinner at the home of the President whose wife waited
on table
- a rare but very
gracious gesture.
At 9:00 p.m. we took the express train back to
Tokyo, arriving here at 7:30 this morning.
The other day a friend presented me with the fol-
lowing piece which will
appeal to the oider ones of you more
than the younger:
"HOW TO GUESS YOUR AGE"
By Corey Ford
"It seems to me that they are building staircases
steeper than they used to.
The risers are higher, or they are
making more of them, or semething.
Maybe this is because it is
so much farther today from the first floor to the second floor,
but I've noticed it is getting harder to make two
steps at a
time any more.
Nowadays it is all I can do to make one step at
a time.
Another thing I've noticed is the small
print they're
using lately.
Newspapers are getting ferther end farther away
when I hold them, and
I have
to squint to make them out.
other day I had to back halfway out of a telephone booth in order
